Hi,

>> I also load tested RMI over IIOP and couldn't manage to
>> load it enough to break it at all.
>>
...
>> I've used JMS in JBoss quite a lot too and you might find that it
>> provides a good way of providing resilience as machines come and go.
>> I can't remember the ins and outs but from what I remember one of the
>> configurations don't cope well with lots of small messages though.

I personal moved away from using heavy j2ee technologies, since I  
think they make things very complicated and slow.
I used jboss and j2ee in general several years and my actually point  
of view is that jboss itself isn't that high quality software any more.

We working on a open source project that is focused on distributed  
computing tools and we decide using simple objects that implements  
the java.io. Externalizable interface and than just using
Sockets Inputstreams and OutputStreams  we wrap into ObjectInput and  
OutputStreams. That is very simple, robust and the fastest possible  
solution.


>>
> Ok. Its something to look at for sure.  As long as we implement  
> against
> JMS interfaces, we can also try other providers (I've worked with  
> Spread
> in the past).
Please take a look to mule.
http://mule.codehaus.org/
"Pluggable connectivity such as Jms (1.0.2b and 1.1), vm (embedded),  
jdbc, tcp, udp, multicast, http, servlet, smtp, pop3, file, xmpp"

Especially multicast could be interesting.

>> For dynamic configuration of the server farm have you considered
>> JINI.
>>
>
> Not seriously.  I've followed it over time.  I have a bias that jini
> still needs work and would be more apt if we were coordinating 100s of
> crawlers rather the 3-10 we're currently trying to get going (3-10  
> will
> be more than a handful)
I agree, we evaluated JINI as well and from my point of view it isn't  
production ready. However we was searching for our project for a  
mechanism to discover new worker nodes in the network and decide to  
use JXTA.
JXTA isn't a good communication mechanism since it is slow (messages  
are send as XML) {as mentioned we using simple sockets and  
serializable objects} but it is a very well mechanism for discover  
and configure nodes in a 'cluster'.

This could be a interesting paper:
http://jngi.jxta.org/jngi-paper.pdf

sorry, just my 2 ... :)

Greetings,
Stefan 
--Apple-Mail-2-450655155
